result.query:
Please find the name of the catalyst and co-catalyst name from the provided context which describe an solar chemical experiment.
Please only generate the name of the catalyst and nothing else. Such as TiO2. ZrO2 or Ag, etc.
Please generating restrictively follow the format, and must start the generation as the format. Do not generate anything else.
If there are multiple results, please indicate them as XXX-XXX.
catalyst: XXX
co_catalyst: XXX

evidence.pdf_reference: Photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 to solar fuels is an ideal approach to simultaneously solve the global warming and energy crisis issues.Constructing a direct Z-scheme heterojunction is an effective way to overcome the drawbacks of single-component or conventional heterogeneous photocatalysts for photocatalytic CO 2 reduction.Here, a novel type of direct Z-scheme g-C 3 N 4 SnS 2 heterojunction was constructed by depositing SnS 2 quantum dots onto the g-C 3 N 4 surface in situ via a simple one-step

photocatalyst was ground with 0.5 mL of ethanol to make a slurry.The slurry was then coated onto a 2 A 1.2 cm F-doped SnO 2 -coated glass (FTO glass) electrode by the doctor blade technique.Next, these electrodes were dried in an oven at 80 C for 30 min.All investigated electrodes have a similar film thickness of 10-11 lm. The CO 2 photoreduction on the photocatalysts in the presence of H 2 O was conducted in a photoreactor similar to that reported in our previous study 7.The photocatalytic CO 2 reduction

Z-scheme charge transfer took place under photoexcitation, with the electrons in SnS 2 combining with the holes in g-C 3 N 4 , which improved the extraction and utilization of photoinduced electron in g-C 3 N 4 .The g-C 3 N 4 SnS 2 hybrid shows superior photocatalytic CO 2 reduction as compared with individual g-C 3 N 4 and SnS 2 , which should be attributed to the IEF-induced direct Zscheme as well as improved CO 2 adsorption capacity.In situ FTIR spectra illustrate that HCOOH appeared as an intermediate

hydrocarbons in this experiment did not originate from the carbon-containing photocatalysts (g-C 3 N 4 ) or carbon contamination.As displayed in Fig. 9, the main products of photocatalytic CO 2 reduction are CH 4 and CH 3 OH, two important storable fuels.Compared with other products (HCOOH, HCHO, etc.), the conversion of CO 2 to CH 4 or to CH 3 OH occurs at higher potential (lower electron energy) but requires more electrons to be involved.Possible reactions and products related to CO 2 reduction as well

to CO 2 reduction as well as the corresponding standard redox potentials from thermodynamic data in this paper are presented in Table 2 52. Fig. 9a shows a comparison of photocatalytic generation yield of CH 4 and CH 3 OH under visible light illumination for the first hour over different samples.We note that only CH 3 OH was detected as the product for individual g-C 3 N 4 and SnS 2 , with yields of 1.2 and 0.8 lmol g A1 , respectively.It is worth mentioning that although g-C 3 N 4 has smaller specific

The generation condition of the extraction is given: If Light_source is Solar or Solar Simulator, Lamp is always Solar Simulator.

(FTIR) and in situ FTIR spectra.Electrochemical measurements were implemented on an electrochemical analyzer (CHI660C, China) in a standard three-electrode system with the as-prepared samples as the working electrode, a Pt wire as the counter electrode, and AgAgCl (saturated KCl) as a reference electrode.A 420 nm LED light was utilized as the light source.A Na 2 SO 4 (0.5 M) aqueous solution was used as the electrolyte.The working electrodes were prepared as follows: 0.05 g of photocatalyst was ground with

conducted under visible light irradiation (k !420 nm) at atmospheric pressure.Control experiments showed that hydrocarbons were undetected in the absence of photocatalysts or irradiation, indicating that effective photocatalysis and illumination are two essential factors for CO 2 reduction.Further control experiment was conducted without the addition of a carbon source but using N 2 as the carrier gas.No hydrocarbons were yielded after illumination for 1 h, indicating that hydrocarbons in this experiment

light was on, resulting from the vast recombination of photogenerated electron-hole pairs at the initial time of irradiation 32.Then the photocurrent decreased and remained almost constant, due to the equilibration between separation and recombination of electronhole pairs 64.

irradiation.For g-C 3 N 4 , continuously increased CH 3 OH production was observed under illumination, and CH 4 started to appear as another product after 3 h irradiation.In contrast, only CH 3 OH was detected over SnS 2 even after 3 h illumination.For g-C 3 N 4 SnS 2 , both CH 3 OH and CH 4 were detected as the illumination started.In the first hour, CH 3 OH showed a much higher yield than CH 4 .With the prolongation of illumination, the generation rate of CH 3 OH declined and its amount became comparable

was analyzed using a gas chromatograph (GC-2014C, Shimadzu) equipped with a flame ionized detector (FID) and a methanizer.The reduced products in this experiment were calibrated with a standard gas mixture and determined from the retention time. Density functional theory (DFT) calculation was carried out using the CASTEP module in the Materials Studio software.The Per dewABurkeAErnzerhof (PBE) exchange-correlation functional was employed within the generalized gradient approximation (GGA).A cutoff energy

photocatalytic CO 2 reduction was carried out in a 200 mL homemade Pyrex reactor with two openings at ambient temperature and atmospheric pressure 32.Particularly, 50 mg of sample was uniformly dispersed in 10 mL of deionized water by ultrasonication, preheated to 80 C, and then maintained for 2 h to evaporate water and deposited on the bottom of the reactor, forming a smooth and thin film.The two openings of the reactor are sealed with rubber stoppers, and N 2 was blown through the reactor to ensure
